coverage: Comprehensive Jeremiah: prophet, priestly lineage, scribal circle, protectors and opponents; last kings of Judah; foreign powers (Egypt, Babylon) and officials; true and false prophets; remnant groups, exiles, Rechabites; full nation oracles (46–51); temple sermon and Shiloh precedent; major sign-acts (yoke, broken flask, field purchase), parables (figs, potter), call visions (almond, boiling pot); new covenant, Branch of David, letter to exiles; apocalyptic horizons (seventy years, return, universal judgment, fall of Babylon, covenant with day and night); idols opposed (Baal, Molech, Queen of Heaven); key places (Anathoth, Ramah, Topheth, Tahpanhes, Euphrates); and Jeremiah’s five confessions. MDiv-level commentary with stable cross-book IDs.
id_scheme: Cross-book stable by (type+primary-slug) with alias support; deterministic for new entries; reuses shared entities (YHWH/Zion/Hezekiah, nations) when present.

entries.name: Jeremiah son of Hilkiah
entries.blurb: Priest from Anathoth called as a youth to be a fortified city and iron pillar. His ministry is marked by ‘confessions’—raw prayers of pain and fidelity—and by enacted signs that interpret Judah’s fall as covenant justice and future hope.

entries.name: Hilkiah (priest of Anathoth, father of Jeremiah)
entries.blurb: Priestly lineage roots Jeremiah’s message in covenant law; not to be confused with Hilkiah the high priest of Josiah’s reform.

entries.name: Baruch son of Neriah (scribe)
entries.blurb: Trusted scribe who writes, reads, and rewrites the burned scroll. Receives a personal oracle (ch. 45) promising life as spoil in days of upheaval.

entries.name: Seraiah son of Neriah (quartermaster/official)
entries.blurb: Carries Jeremiah’s scroll to Babylon with Zedekiah’s entourage; reads the oracle against Babylon and sinks the scroll in the Euphrates as enacted end of the empire.

entries.name: Ebed-melech the Cushite (court eunuch)
entries.blurb: Foreign courtier who risks favor to rescue Jeremiah from the cistern; receives a promise of deliverance for trusting the LORD.

entries.name: Ahikam son of Shaphan
entries.blurb: Statesman who protects Jeremiah in early ministry, echoing Shaphan’s reform legacy under Josiah.

entries.name: Gedaliah son of Ahikam (governor)
entries.blurb: Appointed by Babylon over the remnant at Mizpah; advocates submission for survival. Assassinated by Ishmael, precipitating flight to Egypt.

entries.name: Ishmael son of Nethaniah
entries.blurb: Royal descendant who murders Gedaliah and many others; his coup fragments the remnant and deepens chaos.

entries.name: Johanan son of Kareah
entries.blurb: Military leader who warns Gedaliah, rescues captives from Ishmael, then disregards Jeremiah’s counsel and drags the remnant to Egypt.

entries.name: Baalis king of Ammon
entries.blurb: Foreign instigator who commissions Ishmael to assassinate Gedaliah—regional politics entangle the remnant.

entries.name: Hanamel son of Shallum (cousin)
entries.blurb: Relative from whom Jeremiah buys the Anathoth field; the deed is sealed as a sign that houses and fields will again be possessed in the land.

entries.name: Irijah son of Shelemiah (guard)
entries.blurb: Accuses Jeremiah of desertion; embodies suspicion and breakdown of trust in a collapsing city.

entries.name: Pilgrims from Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria
entries.blurb: Eighty mourners with offerings arrive after Jerusalem’s fall and are slaughtered by Ishmael—piety caught in political violence.

entries.name: Josiah king of Judah
entries.blurb: Reforming king lamented by Jeremiah; his death at Megiddo marks a hinge toward Judah’s unraveling.

entries.name: Jehoahaz (Shallum) king of Judah
entries.blurb: Reigns three months; exiled to Egypt. Jeremiah instructs not to weep for the dead but for the exile—displacement is the sharper grief.

entries.name: Jehoiakim (Eliakim) king of Judah
entries.blurb: Builds with injustice, sheds innocent blood, burns the scroll; prophecy declares a donkey’s burial—disgrace for a king who scorned the word.

entries.name: Jehoiachin (Coniah/Jeconiah) king of Judah
entries.blurb: Exiled to Babylon; ‘write this man childless’ declares judgment on his line, yet hope flickers in later restoration narratives.

entries.name: Zedekiah (Mattaniah) king of Judah
entries.blurb: Vacillates between fear and inquiry; repeatedly consults Jeremiah but refuses obedience—tragic figure presiding over the fall.

entries.name: Pharaoh Necho II of Egypt
entries.blurb: Defeats Josiah at Megiddo and installs Jehoiakim; Egypt appears both as temptation and as judged nation in Jeremiah’s oracles.

entries.name: Hophra (Apries) of Egypt
entries.blurb: Pharaoh named in Jeremiah’s Egypt oracles; his fall is prophesied as a sign to exiles in Egypt.

entries.name: Nebuchadnezzar II of Babylon (‘my servant’)
entries.blurb: YHWH calls the pagan emperor ‘my servant’—divine sovereignty bends empires for judgment and restoration.

entries.name: Nebuzaradan (captain of the guard)
entries.blurb: Babylonian official who burns the city, releases Jeremiah, and appoints Gedaliah; an instrument of ordered judgment.

entries.name: Evil‑Merodach (Amel‑Marduk) king of Babylon
entries.blurb: Elevates Jehoiachin from prison; tiny mercy at the exile’s end foreshadows future kindnesses.

entries.name: Babylonian princes at Jerusalem’s fall
entries.blurb: Nergal‑sharezer, Samgar‑nebo, Sarsechim, and others—named officials embody the bureaucratic machinery of conquest.

entries.name: Envoys of Edom, Moab, Ammon, Tyre, Sidon to Zedekiah
entries.blurb: Regional diplomats receive Jeremiah’s yoke‑message: submit to Babylon and live—prudence under providence.

entries.name: Uriah son of Shemaiah (true prophet)
entries.blurb: Prophesies like Jeremiah, flees to Egypt, yet is extradited and killed by Jehoiakim—truth is costly in regimes of fear.

entries.name: Hananiah son of Azzur (false prophet)
entries.blurb: Breaks Jeremiah’s wooden yoke and promises quick deliverance; dies within the year by the word of the LORD—presumption exposed.

entries.name: Pashhur son of Immer (temple priest)
entries.blurb: Beats Jeremiah and puts him in stocks; receives a name‑oracle ‘Terror on Every Side’ (Magor‑missabib) forecasting exile.

entries.name: Pashhur son of Malchiah (official)
entries.blurb: Court official allied with princes who push for Jeremiah’s execution and cistern‑imprisonment.

entries.name: Shemaiah the Nehelamite (false prophet)
entries.blurb: Writes from exile to silence Jeremiah; the LORD rebukes his letters as lies.

entries.name: Ahab son of Kolaiah & Zedekiah son of Maaseiah
entries.blurb: False prophets in Babylon—condemned for lies and immorality; Babylon becomes their judgment ground.

entries.name: Prophets of lies, diviners, dreamers
entries.blurb: A composite category of religious entrepreneurs who soothe consciences and subvert repentance; Jeremiah insists on submission to God’s discipline.

entries.name: Priests and men of Anathoth
entries.blurb: Jeremiah’s own town plots against him—persecution can be intimate; covenant treachery begins at home.

entries.name: Shepherds of Israel (leaders)
entries.blurb: Destroy and scatter the sheep; God promises to raise faithful shepherds and a righteous Branch.

entries.name: Court princes of Judah
entries.blurb: A mixed group—some seek Jeremiah’s life, others shield him; politics of the last days are factional.

entries.name: Rechabites
entries.blurb: Nomadic clan who obey their ancestor’s command by abstaining from wine and city life—embarrassing Judah by embodied obedience.

entries.name: Remnant in Judah
entries.blurb: Those left in the land after deportations; fragile governance under Gedaliah collapses into fear and flight.

entries.name: Remnant in Egypt
entries.blurb: Against prophetic counsel, the remnant drags Jeremiah to Egypt and persists in idolatry—exile does not guarantee repentance.

entries.name: Exiles in Babylon
entries.blurb: Recipients of Jeremiah’s letter to build, plant, marry, seek the city’s shalom—exile as long obedience.

entries.name: Women baking cakes for the Queen of Heaven
entries.blurb: Household piety enshrines idolatry; women’s agency is named yet redirected toward covenant fidelity.

entries.name: Chaldeans (Babylonians)
entries.blurb: Military arm of Babylon—agents of the siege and torchbearers of judgment.

entries.name: Egypt (Jeremiah)
entries.blurb: Oracle against Egypt: from Carchemish to the day of disaster—YHWH’s sword has a mission even among empires.

entries.name: Philistia (Jeremiah)
entries.blurb: Sword of the LORD unsheathed along the coast—lament for Gaza and Ashkelon.

entries.name: Moab (Jeremiah)
entries.blurb: Long taunt and lament; Moab’s pride is shattered, yet a latter‑day restoration glimmers.

entries.name: Ammon (Jeremiah)
entries.blurb: Questions over Milcom’s inheritance; promise of restoration after judgment.

entries.name: Edom (Jeremiah)
entries.blurb: Wisdom confounded in Teman; eagle imagery signals swift descent.

entries.name: Damascus (Jeremiah)
entries.blurb: City of fame becomes feeble; fire in Ben‑hadad’s palace.

entries.name: Kedar and Hazor
entries.blurb: Desert tribes struck by Nebuchadnezzar—tents, flocks, and curtains plundered.

entries.name: Elam (Jeremiah)
entries.blurb: Bow of Elam broken; in the latter days a restorative promise rises.

entries.name: Babylon (Jeremiah)
entries.blurb: Hammer of the whole earth shattered; pride and idolatry judged; Israel and Judah seek the LORD together.

entries.name: The Temple (Sermon at the Gate)
entries.blurb: False security in sacred space is rebuked; obedience outranks ritual. Shiloh proves God’s willingness to raze His own house for righteousness.

entries.name: Shiloh precedent
entries.blurb: Historic sanctuary destroyed—living memory leveraged as warning against presumption.

entries.name: New Covenant (law on the heart)
entries.blurb: Climactic promise of inwardized Torah, universal knowledge of God, and forgiven sin; later cited in Hebrews as fulfilled in Christ.

entries.name: Cup of wrath to the nations
entries.blurb: Jeremiah makes nations drink the cup—symbol of inescapable judgment that levels geopolitical pretensions.

entries.name: Good and bad figs
entries.blurb: Parable of exiles (good) who will be restored vs. those clinging to the land (bad) who face sword, famine, and pestilence.

entries.name: Almond tree branch vision
entries.blurb: Wordplay: shoqed/shoqed—God watches over His word to perform it; call vision anchors ministry in divine vigilance.

entries.name: Boiling pot from the north
entries.blurb: Judgment tilts toward Jerusalem from the north—Babylon’s approach mapped in metaphor.

entries.name: Yoke and bonds sign‑act
entries.blurb: Wooden (then iron) yokes dramatize submission to Babylon as God’s discipline; resisting is courting ruin.

entries.name: Scroll burned and rewritten
entries.blurb: Jehoiakim burns; Jeremiah dictates again—God’s word proves fireproof by resilience.

entries.name: Potter and clay
entries.blurb: Divine sovereignty and responsive judgment—clay can be reworked; nations can repent and live.

entries.name: Broken flask in the Valley of Hinnom (Topheth)
entries.blurb: Irreversible ruin sign‑acted at the place of child sacrifice; horror meets holiness.

entries.name: Rachel weeping for her children
entries.blurb: Personified grief at Ramah over exiles; comfort promised. Later echoed in Matthew 2:18.

entries.name: The LORD, fountain of living waters
entries.blurb: Cistern‑digging folly vs. covenant spring—metaphor diagnoses idolatry as thirst misdirected.

entries.name: Jeremiah as iron pillar and bronze wall
entries.blurb: Prophetic identity: fortified against kings, officials, priests, and people—courage by calling.

entries.name: Field of Hanamel (sealed deed)
entries.blurb: Purchase deed stored in earthenware—down payment on restoration during siege.

entries.name: Seventy years of exile
entries.blurb: A fixed term for Babylon’s dominion; hope is calendared without being cheapened.

entries.name: Letter to the exiles
entries.blurb: Build, plant, marry, seek the city’s shalom; pray for the city—exile as vocation, not mere penalty.

entries.name: Book of Consolation (Jeremiah 30–33)
entries.blurb: A cluster of salvation oracles: new covenant, restored Zion, Branch of David, and joyful city—judgment serves joy.

entries.name: Branch of David / ‘The LORD is our righteousness’
entries.blurb: Righteous ruler who executes justice; the city shares His name—civic holiness by royal grace.

entries.name: Gathering of the remnant / Good shepherds
entries.blurb: Scattered flock regathered; shepherds after God’s heart replace exploiters—pastoral blueprint for restoration.

entries.name: ‘Terror on Every Side’ (Magor‑missabib) motif
entries.blurb: Catchphrase of dread that stalks the narrative—social unraveling voiced as a refrain.

entries.name: Promise of return after seventy years
entries.blurb: I will visit you and fulfill my promise—seeking God with whole heart finds Him even in exile.

entries.name: Fall of Babylon (Jeremiah)
entries.blurb: Comprehensive takedown of the proud empire—idols exposed, captives recalled; scroll sunk in Euphrates seals the word.

entries.name: Universal judgment of the nations
entries.blurb: From Jerusalem outward, the cup circulates—no refuge in geopolitics when the Judge arises.

entries.name: Covenant with day and night
entries.blurb: If the fixed order could be broken, then Davidic and Levitical promises might fail—creation itself guarantees covenant fidelity.

entries.name: Rebuilt Jerusalem, measured and holy
entries.blurb: Surveyed from the Tower of Hananel to the Corner Gate; the valley of dead bodies becomes sacred to the LORD—cartography of hope.

entries.name: Baal worship in Judah
entries.blurb: Altars as numerous as streets; prophetic polemic targets covenant infidelity masquerading as piety.

entries.name: Molech / Topheth sacrifices
entries.blurb: Child sacrifice condemned; Valley of Hinnom renamed slaughter—horror meets the holiness of God.

entries.name: Queen of Heaven
entries.blurb: Popular goddess venerated with cakes, libations, and incense—Jeremiah indicts the practice as covenant treason.

entries.name: Wood and stone (generic idols)
entries.blurb: You say to a tree, ‘You are my father’—satire of dependency on what cannot save.

entries.name: Anathoth (priestly town)
entries.blurb: Jeremiah’s hometown—source of both identity and opposition; site of the field purchase sign.

entries.name: Ramah (Rachel’s weeping)
entries.blurb: Checkpoint north of Jerusalem associated with deportations; grief voices hope’s need.

entries.name: Topheth / Valley of Hinnom (Gehenna)
entries.blurb: Site of child sacrifice and prophetic shattering of the flask; later Jewish imagination associates it with eschatological judgment.

entries.name: Tahpanhes (Daphnae) in Egypt
entries.blurb: Jeremiah buries stones at Pharaoh’s house as a sign that Nebuchadnezzar will spread his canopy there—exile follows disobedience.

entries.name: Migdol, Noph (Memphis), and Pathros (Upper Egypt)
entries.blurb: Destinations of the Judean remnant in Egypt—diaspora mapped for judgment or mercy.

entries.name: Euphrates (Perath) River
entries.blurb: Linen loincloth hidden and ruined; Babylon‑scroll sunk—river as theater of humiliation and empire’s end.

entries.name: Confession I: Plotted against, yet trusted
entries.blurb: Jeremiah wrestles with divine justice and betrayal by his own town; God answers with a call to endurance—if you stumble with footmen, how will you compete with horses?

entries.name: Confession II: Woe is me, my mother
entries.blurb: Loneliness and insult weigh on the prophet; the LORD’s word is joy yet isolates him—promise of strengthened wall renews vocation.

entries.name: Confession III: Heal me, O LORD
entries.blurb: Prayer for vindication amid mockery; Jeremiah entrusts vengeance to God rather than personal retaliation.

entries.name: Confession IV: Plot against the prophet
entries.blurb: ‘Come, let us strike the prophet with the tongue’—Jeremiah pleads for justice against conspirators.

entries.name: Confession V: You deceived me, O LORD
entries.blurb: The fiercest lament swings from compulsion to curse of birth; yet a fire in his bones will not let him keep silent.
